prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
We perhaps should not be surprised that the prime minister has seized upon an extrapolation of Thursday's local election results that pointed to the prospect that the general election could result in a hung parliament in which Labour would be the largest party.

Such a scenario, he argued, would mean that Sir Keir Starmer would be "propped up in Downing Street" by the SNP, the Liberal Democrats, and the Greens.

Many Conservative MPs (and indeed Labour ones too) believe that a poster their party ran in the 2015 election, when the polls were pointing to a hung parliament, showing the then Labour leader, Ed Miliband, in the pocket of the former SNP leader, Alex Salmond, played a key role in delivering the Conservatives a surprise overall majority.

Whether or not that is what happened is not easy for analysts to say. However, British Election Study data collected at the time did not show any marked swing away from Labour among those who came to believe that Mr Miliband would be willing to do a deal with the SNP.

But, in any event, how realistic is it to use the share of the vote won by the parties in local elections to anticipate what might happen in an immediate general election? There are certainly two potential difficulties.

Although the ups and downs in party performance in local elections often run in parallel with the rises and falls in party support in the polls, some people (around one in five) vote differently in local elections than they would in a general election.

As a result the divergence between the level of support parties win in a local election and how well they would perform in a general election has become more marked.

Nowadays the Liberal Democrats consistently outperform their national standing in the local ballot boxes. The same has also come to be true of the Greens, while independent candidates have also enjoyed some notable success in recent years. Labour, in contrast, often do less well in local elections.

Meanwhile, the party political battle in Scotland is now very different from that in England - and the outcome of the current battle north of the border between Labour and the SNP could be crucial to the result of the next election. English local elections do not tell us much about what will happen north of the border.

These developments have made discerning the implications of local elections for the outcome of a general election more difficult.

At the same time, there are two particular features of the results of this year's local elections that make it especially difficult.

First, the polls suggest that more people who voted Conservative in 2019 have now switched to Reform than to Labour. But Reform were only on the ballot paper in one in six council wards. So, it may well be the case that people who would vote Reform if there had been a Reform candidate locally stuck with the Tories instead.

Certainly, Conservative support fell more heavily where Reform did stand. In the BBC's sample of key wards the party's support fell by 19 points in these wards - compared with 11 points in wards where Reform did not stand. Labour, in contrast, did rather better where Reform stood.

That 19-point drop matches the 19-point fall in the average level of Conservative support in the polls since May 2021. That figure may represent a better guide to the Conservatives' immediate prospects in a general election.

Second, the local election results confirm the message from last year's contests that the geography of party support has changed to the Conservatives' disadvantage.

The party's support fell more heavily in wards it was trying to defend.

At the same time, some voters seemingly voted for whichever party was best placed to defeat the Conservatives locally. Labour's support increased most (at the expense of the Liberal Democrats) in wards where they started off second to the Conservatives, while the Liberal Democrats advanced most (and Labour did less well) in wards where were the principal challengers locally.

Indeed, it is these two patterns that help explain why the Conservative Party lost nearly one in two of the council seats it was trying to defend. Conservative MPs would be unwise to assume that the same fate could not also befall them.

Sir John Curtice is Professor of Politics, University of Strathclyde, and Senior Fellow, National Centre for Social Research and 'The UK in a Changing Europe'. He is also co-host of the Trendy podcast.
stories:
It's no surprise that the prime minister has latched onto a projection of Thursday's local election results, which suggests that the next general election could result in a hung parliament with Labour as the largest party. 

The prime minister argues that in such a scenario, Sir Keir Starmer would be reliant on the support of the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Greens to govern. 

Many Conservative MPs, as well as Labour ones, believe that a 2015 election poster depicting Ed Miliband in Alex Salmond's pocket contributed to the Conservatives' surprise majority win that year. 

However, analysis of British Election Study data from the time doesn't show a significant swing away from Labour among voters who believed Miliband would do a deal with the SNP. 

But how reliable is it to use local election results to predict the outcome of a general election? There are two major issues to consider. 

Firstly, although local election trends often mirror national polling trends, around one in five voters cast their ballots differently in local and general elections. 

As a result, the gap between local and general election performances has widened. The Liberal Democrats and Greens tend to perform better in local elections, while Labour often underperforms. 

Furthermore, the political landscape in Scotland is now distinct from that in England, and the outcome of the Labour-SNP battle in Scotland could be crucial to the next election. 

Two features of this year's local election results make it particularly challenging to draw conclusions about the general election. 

Firstly, the polls suggest that more 2019 Conservative voters have switched to Reform than Labour, but Reform only stood in one-sixth of council wards. This may mean that would-be Reform voters stuck with the Conservatives instead. 

Secondly, the local election results confirm that the geography of party support has shifted to the Conservatives' disadvantage. 

The party's support fell more heavily in wards it was defending, and some voters seemingly backed the party best placed to defeat the Conservatives locally. 

These patterns help explain why the Conservatives lost nearly half of the council seats they were defending, and Conservative MPs would be wise not to assume the same fate couldn't befall them in a general election.

The prime minister's attention to a forecast of Thursday's local election results, suggesting a hung parliament with Labour as the largest party in the next general election, comes as no surprise. 

According to the prime minister, in such a scenario, Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer would need the backing of the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Greens to form a government. 

Many Conservative and Labour MPs believe that a 2015 election poster showing Ed Miliband in Alex Salmond's pocket contributed to the Conservatives' unexpected majority win that year. 

However, analysis of British Election Study data from the time reveals no significant shift away from Labour among voters who thought Miliband would collaborate with the SNP. 

But can local election results be trusted to predict the outcome of a general election? There are two key considerations to take into account. 

Firstly, although local election trends often echo national polling trends, around one in five voters cast their ballots differently in local and general elections, leading to a widening gap between local and general election performances. 

Additionally, the political landscape in Scotland has diverged from that in England, and the Labour-SNP battle in Scotland could be pivotal to the next election. 

This year's local election results present two significant challenges to drawing conclusions about the general election. 

Firstly, polls indicate that more 2019 Conservative voters have defected to Reform rather than Labour, but Reform only contested one-sixth of council wards, potentially leading would-be Reform voters to stick with the Conservatives instead. 

Secondly, the local election results confirm a shift in the geography of party support to the Conservatives' detriment. 

The party's support declined more heavily in wards it was defending, with some voters seemingly backing the party best placed to defeat the Conservatives locally, which helps explain why the Conservatives lost nearly half of the council seats they were defending. Conservative MPs should not assume that the same fate cannot befall them in a general election.

In such a scenario, the prime minister stresses that Labour's Sir Keir Starmer would need to secure the backing of the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Greens to establish a government. Contrary to popular opinion, an analysis of British Election Study data reveals that the infamous 2015 campaign poster featuring Ed Miliband and Alex Salmond had no significant impact on Labour's support among voters who believed Miliband would collaborate with the SNP. When forecasting the general election outcome based on local election results, two key considerations are essential. Firstly, although local election trends often reflect national polling trends, around 20% of voters cast different ballots in local and general elections, resulting in a disparity between local and general election performances. Secondly, the political landscape in Scotland has diverged from that in England, making the Labour-SNP contest in Scotland potentially pivotal in the next election. This year's local election results pose two significant challenges to drawing conclusions about the general election. Firstly, polls suggest that more 2019 Conservative voters have defected to Reform rather than Labour, but Reform's limited participation in council wards may have led potential Reform voters to stick with the Conservatives. Secondly, the local election results confirm a shift in the geographic distribution of party support, to the detriment of the Conservatives, who lost nearly half of the council seats they were defending, a fate that Conservative MPs should not assume they will avoid in a general election.

The prime minister is concerned that the latest local election outcomes may lead to a hung parliament, where Labour becomes the largest party but falls short of a majority. To assume power, Labour's leader, Sir Keir Starmer, would need to form alliances with the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Greens, a point the prime minister is keen to stress. Despite common perception, analysis of British Election Study data shows that the 2015 campaign poster featuring Ed Miliband and Alex Salmond had no significant impact on Labour's popularity among voters who suspected Miliband would collaborate with the SNP. When predicting the general election outcome based on local election results, two essential factors must be considered. Firstly, while local election trends often reflect national polling trends, around 20% of voters cast different ballots in local and general elections, resulting in a disparity between local and general election performances. Secondly, the political landscape in Scotland has diverged from that in England, making the Labour-SNP contest in Scotland potentially decisive in the next election. This year's local election results pose two significant challenges to predicting the general election. Firstly, polls suggest that more 2019 Conservative voters have defected to Reform rather than Labour, but Reform's limited presence in council wards may have led potential Reform voters to stick with the Conservatives. Secondly, the local election results confirm a shift in the geographic distribution of party support, to the detriment of the Conservatives, who lost nearly half of the council seats they were defending – a fate that Conservative MPs should not assume they will avoid in a general election.
